parts.text:
```xml
<output>
<analysis>
<has-cmf>The provided Facebook post does not contain a CMF number.  While the absence of a CMF number doesn't automatically exclude it from being considered electoral propaganda, it suggests it might not be directly linked to an official campaign.</has-cmf>
<refers-to-candidate>The post refers to "Gheorghe Valentin Rotar - Primar," who is clearly identified as the mayor of Blaj. However, the post doesn't explicitly mention any parliamentary candidacy or election. The content focuses on his achievements as mayor and expresses pride in Blaj.  While he holds a political office, the post doesn't directly advocate for his election to a parliamentary position.</refers-to-candidate>
<addresses-the-wide-population>The post is a paid advertisement on Facebook, a public platform.  It's designed to reach a wide audience, not just a select group of individuals. The use of hashtags and emoticons further suggests an attempt to reach a broader public.</addresses-the-wide-population>
<electoral-objective>The primary objective of the post seems to be to promote the image and achievements of Gheorghe Valentin Rotar as the mayor of Blaj. While this indirectly benefits his political career, the post doesn't explicitly urge voters to elect him for any specific office. The focus is on civic pride and local accomplishments, not on influencing votes in a parliamentary election.</electoral-objective>
<journalism>The post could be considered a form of self-promotion by a public figure. It's not strictly journalistic in nature, but it doesn't employ the tactics of typical electoral propaganda. The content is more akin to a positive image-building exercise than an attempt to sway voters in an election.</journalism>
<personal_opinion>The post expresses pride and positive sentiment towards Blaj and its mayor.  It's presented as a personal statement, not an attempt to manipulate public opinion regarding a specific election.</personal_opinion>
</analysis>

<conclusion>
<post_id>533481532845298</post_id>
<electoral-propaganda-analysis>
The post, while promoting a political figure, does not directly advocate for a vote in the parliamentary elections.  The content focuses on the mayor's achievements and expresses pride in the city.  The absence of explicit calls to vote for a specific candidate, combined with the lack of a CMF number, weakens the case for classifying it as electoral propaganda.  While the post could indirectly benefit the mayor's political standing, this indirect benefit alone is insufficient to constitute a violation of Article 98 t).
</electoral-propaganda-analysis>
<electoral-propaganda-decision>FALSE</electoral-propaganda-decision>
<electoral-propaganda-candidates/>
<responsible-party-or-group>INDEPENDENT</responsible-party-or-group>
<message-for-police/>
</conclusion>
</output>
```
